docs.lead_paragraph: New Normal on Wall Street: Smaller and Restrained  |  With firms like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley reporting weak results for last year, Wall Street is having to confront doubts about itself.

headline.main: Is U.S. Health Spending Finally Under Control?

docs.abstract: At some point, we may reasonably assume, spending on health care will not increase faster than gross domestic product, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: At some point, we may reasonably assume, spending on health care will not increase faster than gross domestic product, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: South Carolinians cringe when reporters descend for the primaries every four years, knowing that the colorful foibles they embrace do not necessarily translate well.

headline.seo: South Carolina Loves Its Quirks but Not Its Critics
headline.main: From South Carolina, a Wary Welcome
headline.print_headline: From South Carolina, a Wary Welcome

docs.abstract: Residents of South Carolina have begun cringing as the national news media, including many Northerners, invade the state; reporters search for quirky and colorful foibles they can present to a nationwide audience, to the embarrassment of many South Carolinians.
docs.snippet: South Carolinians cringe when reporters descend for the primaries every four years, knowing that the colorful foibles they embrace do not necessarily translate well.

docs.lead_paragraph: An arrest offers no comfort for a Brooklyn community that has been rattled by the recent spate of crimes.

headline.seo: In Brooklyn, Anti-Semitic Crimes Bring Painful Memories
headline.main: After Anti-Semitic Crimes, Revisiting the Nightmares Forever Within
headline.print_headline: After Anti-Semitic Crimes, Revisiting the Nightmares Forever Within

docs.abstract: Holocaust survivors speak out against recent spate of anti-Semitic crimes in Brooklyn, Manhattan and New Jersey and on Long Island; arrest of David Haddad, a 56-year old Jewish man who had business disputes with some of the victims, has done little to ease the anxiety and disbelief.
docs.snippet: An arrest offers no comfort for a Brooklyn community that has been rattled by the recent spate of crimes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate quickly turned back to the prevailing issues of the Republican presidential campaign, with Newt Gingrich continuing his criticism of Mitt Romney.

headline.seo: Debate Opens With Questions on Gingrich’s Marriages
headline.main: Gingrich Jousts With Rivals on Matters Professional and Personal
headline.print_headline: Gingrich Jousts With Rivals on Matters Professional and Personal

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich angrily turns aside questions about his marital history at the outset of the final Republican presidential debate before the South Carolina primary, and then aggressively takes on Mitt Romney and the other remaining candidates in an intensely personal verbal combat fittingly set in a North Charleston sports coliseum.
docs.snippet: The debate quickly turned back to the prevailing issues of the Republican presidential campaign, with Newt Gingrich continuing his criticism of Mitt Romney.

byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and JEFF ZELENY

docs.lead_paragraph: As Mitt Romney dances around calls for him to release his tax returns, a question about U.S. tax policy comes up: Why do the rich bear a startlingly light tax burden?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column suggests the larger question of Mitt Romney's tax returns is not what they have to say about Mitt Romney but rather what they reveal about tax policy in the United States; deplores fact that the rich bear a startlingly light tax burden compared to the poor and middle class.
docs.snippet: As Mitt Romney dances around calls for him to release his tax returns, a question about U.S. tax policy comes up: Why do the rich bear a startlingly light tax burden?

docs.lead_paragraph: Fourth-quarter profit rose 21 percent, to $1.26 billion, or $1.17 a share, compared with $1.04 billion, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier.
docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group reports fourth-quarter earnings that beat analysts estimates after the company gained members and controlled costs; net income climbed 21 percent, to $1.26 billion, or $1.17 a share, compared with $1.04 billion, or 94 cents a share, in year-ago quarter.
docs.snippet: Fourth-quarter profit rose 21 percent, to $1.26 billion, or $1.17 a share, compared with $1.04 billion, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier.

docs.snippet: A reader responds to a news article, “U.S. Seeks Rollback of a Health Insurer’s ‘Excessive’ Rate Increase.”

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: When Mitt Romney said that his federal tax rate was about 15 percent, many wrongly assumed that their own rate was higher.

headline.seo: Why Americans Think the Tax Rate’s High, and Why They’re Wrong
headline.main: Why Taxes Aren’t as High as They Seem
headline.print_headline: Why Taxes Aren’t as High as They Seem

docs.abstract: News analysis holds that the disconnect between what most Americans pay in federal income taxes and what they think they pay is nothing less than one of the country's biggest economic problems; many Americans see themselves as struggling under the weight of a heavy tax burden, when in fact taxes in the United States are quite low compared with past years or those in other countries; reality is that tax rates are insufficient to pay for many popular programs, like Medicare, and the result is an enormous long-term budget deficit.
docs.snippet: When Mitt Romney said that his federal tax rate was about 15 percent, many wrongly assumed that their own rate was higher.
